rule: Ryffine uses DITA maps as the top-level containers for all deliverables.
Use maps to organize content by use case or feature.
Use maps to organize related topics into single reusable units.
Use maps to organize topics that all relate to a single user goal.
Use maps to divide large sets of related information into smaller, more manageable units.
Use maps to establish relationships between parent/child and sibling topics.
All Ryffine maps must have a <map> base element.
All Ryffine maps must have a <title> element within the <map> element.
All Ryffine maps may optionally have a <topicmeta> element within the <map> element.
All Ryffine maps must have a <topicref> element as the top-level parent container topic for automated linking.
rule_code: <!-- R4: Enforce one initial topicref -->\n      <ref name="topicref"/>

rule: Maps can have any number, at any level, and in any order of <topicgroup>, <mapref>, <topicref>.
rule_code:
<!-- R5: Then allow zeroOrMore of the choices -->
      <zeroOrMore>
        <choice>
          <ref name="topicref"/>
          <ref name="topicgroup"/>
          <ref name="mapref"/>
          <!-- Add glossref here once defined for R9 -->
          <ref name="glossref"/>
        </choice>
      </zeroOrMore>

rule: Maps can optionally have a <reltable> element.
Use the <title> element to define a title for the group of topics in a map.
Metadata specified in a <topicmeta> element cascades to all elements contained within the element to which the <topicmeta> is attached.
Metadata specified in <topicmeta> within a map overrides any metadata values for the same elements specified in the topics, unless multiple elements of that type are allowed.
Use <topicref> to point to a single DITA topic.
<topicref> must include the @href attribute to point to the path and file name for each DITA topic or external file.
Nesting <topicref> elements in one another creates a navigational and hierarchical structure.
Use <mapref> to point to a map of DITA topics.
<mapref> must include the @href attribute to point to the path and file name for the DITA map.
Use <reltable> to specify relationships between topics.
Nest <topicref> elements in a <topicgroup> to establish linking relationships between them.
Use the @collection-type attribute on <topicgroup> to establish the type of relationship.
The 'print' attribute specifies whether the topic should be included in print outputs (default is yes).
Only use 'print=no' if you want to exclude the topic from print output.
The '@processing-role' attribute specifies if the topic is normal or a resource for reusable components.
Only set '@processing-role=resource-only' when the topic is used as a resource only (e.g., key files).
The '@toc' attribute specifies whether topics are included in a site map or table of contents (default is yes).
Only use '@toc=no' if you want to exclude the topic from the table of contents.
The '@chunk=to-content' attribute specifies that all nested topics be combined together as a single topic when processed.
rule_code:
<optional>
        <attribute name="chunk">
          <value>to-content</value> <!-- Only this value is allowed -->
        </attribute>
      </optional>

rule: Only use '@chunk=to-content' if you want multiple topics to be displayed together as one topic in an outline output.
The '@copy-to' attribute specifies a different file name for a particular instance of the topic in the map.
Use '@copy-to' when including the same topic multiple times within the same map to ensure context is maintained.
The '@title' attribute on a map element (e.g. topicref) specifies the title of the map (should be used to add the title of the DITA map if not using the topic's own title).
A map file contains <topicref>, <mapref>, and <glossref> elements in a hierarchic order.
rule_code:
<!-- R4: Enforce one initial topicref -->
      <ref name="topicref"/>
      <!-- R5: Then allow zeroOrMore of the choices -->
      <zeroOrMore>
        <choice>
          <ref name="topicref"/>
          <ref name="topicgroup"/>
          <ref name="mapref"/>
          <!-- Add glossref here once defined for R9 -->
          <ref name="glossref"/>
        </choice>
      </zeroOrMore>

rule: Each of <topicref>, <mapref>, and <glossref> elements requires an @href attribute that points a topic or map.
rule_code: <attribute name="href">\n        <data type="string"/>\n      </attribute> (present in all three definitions)

rule: Map titles tend to be less specific than topic titles.
Map titles should categorize the information in the map.
Ensure the map title indicates the range of topics the map contains.
In any single publication, map titles are closely tied together. Make each map title clearly differentiated.
Avoid starting all map titles with the same words (e.g., product name); put differentiating words first.
All other relationships (non-parent/child) must be explicitly established through attributes or relationship tables.
Using the @collection-type attribute on a <topicref> or <topicgroup>, you can establish links through the hierarchical structure of a map.
@collection-type='family' means all topics within the group are related to all other topics.
@collection-type='sequence' means topics are related to topics immediately before and after them via Next/Previous links.
Specify the @collection-type attribute on the parent topic of the topics you want to link together.
If you don't want to promote one topic over another, first nest related topics in a <topicgroup> and then assign the @collection-type attribute.
When topics are not grouped together within the hierarchy of the map, you must use a relationship table to establish links.

Structure bookmaps with elements in the order shown: <bookmap> (required), <booktitle> (required), <mainbooktitle> (required), <booktitlealt> (optional), <bookmeta> (required), <frontmatter> (required).
rule_code:
<element name="bookmap">
      <ref name="id-atts"/>
      <ref name="lang-atts"/>
      <ref name="booktitle"/>
      <ref name="bookmeta"/>
      <ref name="frontmatter"/>
      <oneOrMore>
        <ref name="chapter"/>
      </oneOrMore>
      <optional>
        <choice>
          <oneOrMore>
            <ref name="appendix"/>
          </oneOrMore>
          <ref name="appendices"/>
        </choice>
      </optional>
      <optional>
        <ref name="backmatter"/>
      </optional>
      <optional>
        <ref name="reltable"/>
      </optional>
    </element>

rule: <frontmatter> must contain <notices> (Legal notices boilerplate).
rule_code:
<optional>
        <ref name="notices"/>
      </optional>
      <optional>
        <ref name="preface"/>
      </optional>
      <optional>
        <ref name="booklists"/>
      </optional>
    </element>
(Note: RNG shows notices as optional, but the text states it must be present for legal notices. Assuming the text rule implies it is used when legal notices are needed, and RNG allows its presence)

rule: <frontmatter> may optionally contain <preface> (must be placed before TOC).
rule_code:
<optional>
        <ref name="preface"/>
      </optional>
(Order relative to TOC is a processing/best practice, RNG defines optional presence)

rule: <frontmatter> may optionally contain <booklists> (which can contain <toc>, <figurelist>, <tablelist>).
<toc> is optional within <booklists>; small documents do not need a toc.
Bookmaps must contain one or more <chapter> elements.
<chapter> elements may optionally contain <topicref> or <mapref> elements.
Bookmaps may contain any number of <appendix> elements (optional).
Bookmaps may contain <backmatter> (optional).
<backmatter> must contain one <topicref> for the Document Revision history topic (required).
rule_code:
<zeroOrMore>
        <ref name="topicref"/>
      </zeroOrMore>
(RNG allows zeroOrMore, the 'one required for rev history' is a content rule. For a strict structural enforcement of *one*, it would need to be <ref name="topicref"/>)

rule: <backmatter> may optionally contain <booklists> (which can contain <indexlist>).
<backmatter> may optionally contain <reltable>.
Use the <booklibrary> element to provide the product family. This element is used in conjunction with <mainbooktitle> and <booktitlealt>.
Use <mainbooktitle> to provide the document type (e.g., Hardware Description, Installation Guide).
Use <booktitlealt> to provide an alternative document title.
Use <bookmeta> as a container for metadata that applies to the entire publication.
Use <frontmatter> as a container for content that belongs before the body of the document.
Use <notices> to provide all legal page content (disclaimers, copyright, trademark lists). Use @href to point to the topic.
To keep front matter topics from appearing in the TOC, set the @toc attribute value to 'no' on the <notices> element.
Use <booklists> as a container for reference lists such as the table of contents.
rule_code:
<element name="booklists">
      <optional>
        <ref name="toc"/>
      </optional>
      <optional>
        <ref name="figurelist"/>
      </optional>
      <optional>
        <ref name="tablelist"/>
      </optional>
      <optional>
        <ref name="indexlist"/>
      </optional>
      <optional>
        <ref name="glossarylist"/>
      </optional>
    </element>

rule: Use <toc> to include a table of contents in the output.
Use the <figurelist> element to include a list of figures (optional). Only figures with a <title> are included.
Use the <tablelist> element to include a list of tables (optional). Only tables with a <title> are included.
Use <preface> to reference a topic or map containing introductory information about a book.
Use the <part> element as a container for related <chapter> elements. Nest a <navtitle> within a <topicmeta> for the part's title.
Use <chapter> to reference a chapter map using the @href attribute. A bookmap should always include at least one <chapter> element.
rule_code:
<element name="chapter">
      <attribute name="href">
        <data type="string"/>
      </attribute>
      <ref name="topicmeta"/>
      <zeroOrMore>
        <choice>
          <ref name="topicref"/>
          <ref name="mapref"/>
        </choice>
      </zeroOrMore>
    </element>

rule: Ryffine uses chapter-level maps to build chapters.
Use <appendices> to group multiple <appendix> elements.
Use <appendix> to reference a chapter map for an appendix using @href. Ryffine uses chapter-level maps for appendices.
rule_code:
<element name="appendix">
      <attribute name="href">
        <data type="string"/>
      </attribute>
      <ref name="topicmeta"/>
      <zeroOrMore>
        <choice>
          <ref name="topicref"/>
          <ref name="mapref"/>
        </choice>
      </zeroOrMore>
    </element>

rule: Use <backmatter> as a container for content that belongs after the body of the document.
Use <indexlist> to include an automatically generated index.
Use <glossarylist> to point to a map of glossary terms using the @href attribute.
The title of your bookmap must be the name of your publication.
Use at least two tags for publication name: <booktitle> (first element), and <mainbooktitle>. Use <booklibrary> for product family.
When titling publications, you can include a descriptor before the document type (e.g., Hardware Description).
Unlike map and topic titles, use title case for publications.
Immediately following the <bookmeta> section, include a <frontmatter> element in the bookmap.
To generate a table of contents, nest a <booklists> element in <frontmatter> and a <toc> element within <booklists>.
<frontmatter> can optionally include <notices> (use @href) and <preface>.
Following the front matter section, include all chapters and appendixes using <chapter> and <appendix> elements with @href attributes.
Within the bookmap, include titles for each chapter/appendix: after <chapter>/<appendix>, nest <topicmeta>, then nest <navtitle> with the title.
Best practice: build each chapter or appendix in a separate map.
If a chapter/appendix has fewer than three topics, consider building it directly in the bookmap (nest <topicref> within <chapter>/<appendix>).
If including a glossary or index, add a <backmatter> element. Inside <backmatter>, add <booklists>, then nest <glossarylist> or <indexlist>.
When adding <glossarylist>, point its @href attribute to the glossary map file.
When adding <indexlist>, do not use the @href attribute; the processor auto-creates it.
Tasks provide procedural, step-by-step instructions for a goal. Answers 'How Do I...'.
Concepts provide overview and background information. Answers 'What is...'.
References provide 'look-up' information. Answers 'How Much...', 'How Many...', 'What Form...'.
Troubleshooting provides information on corrective actions.
Scripts describe a code sample in no more than 1 paragraph.
Field definitions provide details about fields, in a properties table.
All content must be placed into topics based on one of the basic information types.

rule: For Task Topics, use an imperative verb form in the title. Example: Installing the print driver.
For Concept Topics, use a noun phrase in the title. Example: Guidelines for titling concept topics.
For Reference Topics, use noun phrases to describe the reference topic. Example: Valid Values for the XYZ Network Configuration.
For Reference Topics, use the name of the referenced information in the title.
For Reference Topics, title topics for specific categories of reference information consistently (e.g., include 'cables' in all cable topics).
For Troubleshooting Topics, summarize the observable symptom that characterizes the problem in the title.
For Troubleshooting Topics, be as specific as possible regarding the context of the problem in the title.
The required <shortdesc> element immediately follows the <title> element.

rule: Make the short description concise and limit it to two or three sentences.
applicable_to: Task, Concept, Reference, Troubleshooting, Glossary terms, Learning overview, Scripts, Field definitions

rule: For navigation, to group topics under a heading, use the <topichead> element in your map instead of a container topic.
For task short descriptions, include: Why users need to complete the task, When users might need to complete it, Who needs to complete it.
If more than two sentences are needed for task short description details, include it in <context> instead.
For concept short descriptions, include: A summary of the main point, Why this information is important to the user.
For reference short descriptions, include: What the reference item does/is/is used for, The specific type of information provided.
For troubleshooting short descriptions, include: Observable symptoms, When problem might occur, Who can fix it. If more than two sentences, use <condition> instead.
When starting or modifying a topic, add metadata to the <prolog> section.

applicable_to: Task, Concept, Reference, Troubleshooting, Glossary terms, Learning overview, Scripts, Field definitions
rule_code:
<element name="keywords">
      <oneOrMore>
        <choice>
          <ref name="keyword"/>
          <ref name="indexterm"/>
        </choice>
      </oneOrMore>
    </element>
(This rule is about placement within prolog, which is structural)

rule: Task topic structure: <task> (req), <title> (req), <shortdesc> (req), <prolog> (req), <taskbody> (req).
rule_code:
<element name="task">
      <ref name="id-atts"/>
      <ref name="lang-atts"/>
      <ref name="title"/>
      <ref name="shortdesc"/>
      <ref name="prolog"/>
      <ref name="taskbody"/>
    </element>

rule: <taskbody> structure: <prereq> (opt), <context> (opt), <steps> (req) (or <steps-unordered>), <steps-informal>, <result> (opt), <example> (opt), <postreq> (opt).
rule_code:
<element name="taskbody">
      <optional>
        <ref name="prereq"/>
      </optional>
      <optional>
        <ref name="context"/>
      </optional>
      <choice>
        <ref name="steps"/>
        <ref name="steps-unordered"/>
        <ref name="steps-informal"/>
      </choice>
      <optional>
        <ref name="result"/>
      </optional>
      <optional>
        <ref name="example"/>
      </optional>
      <optional>
        <ref name="postreq"/>
      </optional>
    </element>

rule: <steps> can contain <stepsection> (opt, must contain <step>), <step> (can be multiple), <info>, <stepresult>.
rule_code:
<element name="steps">
    <oneOrMore>
      <choice>
        <ref name="step"/>
        <ref name="stepsection"/>
      </choice>
    </oneOrMore>
  </element>
... (step definition shows info, stepresult as optional children)

rule: A task topic must have at least one <steps> or <steps-unordered> element.
rule_code:
<choice>
        <ref name="steps"/>
        <ref name="steps-unordered"/>
        <ref name="steps-informal"/>
      </choice>
(steps-informal also an option, but text states one of steps or steps-unordered, implies steps-informal is a fallback if others not used)

rule: Use <prereq> to specify anything user needs to know/do before starting task. Nest an unordered list for items. Do not include introductory sentence.
rule_code: <element name="prereq">\n      <ref name="ul"/>  <!-- Now only <ul> is allowed -->\n    </element>

rule: Use <context> to identify purpose/goal of task. Should not replace/duplicate related concept topic.
Use <steps> for a numbered list of steps. <steps>, <steps-unordered>, or <steps-informal> is required.
Use <steps-unordered> if task has one step or steps don't need specific order. Formatted with checkboxes.
Use <stepsection> to put a title before a set of steps. Does not interrupt step sequencing.
rule_code:
<element name="stepsection">
    <oneOrMore>
      <ref name="step"/> <!-- Must contain one or more <step> elements -->
    </oneOrMore>
  </element>

rule: Use <result> to describe expected outcome for the task as a whole.
Use <tasktroubleshooting> (optional) to help users resolve problems during a task.
Use <example> in a task to include a specific scenario for completing the task.
rule_code:
<optional>
        <ref name="example"/>
      </optional> (in taskbody)

<element name="example">
      <ref name="id-atts"/>
      <optional>
        <ref name="title"/>
      </optional>
      <oneOrMore>
        <choice>
          <ref name="p"/>
          ...
        </choice>
      </oneOrMore>
    </element>

rule: Use <postreq> to specify anything user needs to know/do after completing the task.
Use <step> for each step. Must be in <steps> or <steps-unordered>. Must begin with <cmd>.
rule_code: <element name="step">\n    <ref name="cmd"/>  <!-- <cmd> is now the first element -->\n    ...

rule: Within <step>, can nest <note> (before <cmd>), <cmd> (required).
rule_code:
<ref name="cmd"/>  <!-- <cmd> is now the first element -->
    <optional>       <!-- Optional <note> can follow <cmd> -->
      <ref name="note"/>
    </optional>

rule: Within <step>, can nest <info> for additional information beyond <cmd> or as container for <note> for specific step.
Use <substeps> to break a step into actions. Contains <substep> elements. <substep> has same structure as <step> but no further <substeps>, <choice>, <choicetable>.
rule_code:
<element name="substeps">
    <oneOrMore>
      <ref name="substep"/>
    </oneOrMore>
  </element>

<element name="substep">
    <ref name="cmd"/>
    <optional>
      <ref name="info"/>
    </optional>
    <optional>
      <ref name="stepresult"/>
    </optional>
  </element>

rule: Use of <substeps> should be limited; only one level of substep permitted. Consider new task instead.
Use <choices> for a list of options. Nest a <choice> element for each option. Do not insert 'or' between choices.
rule_code:
<element name="choices">
    <oneOrMore>
      <ref name="choice"/>
    </oneOrMore>
  </element>

<element name="choice">
    <mixed>
      <zeroOrMore>
        <choice>
          <ref name="common.inline"/>
          <ref name="p"/>
          <ref name="ul"/>
          <ref name="ol"/>
        </choice>
      </zeroOrMore>
    </mixed>
  </element>

rule: Use <choicetable> when user has many options leading to different results (if/then configuration).
rule_code:
<element name="choicetable">
    <ref name="chhead"/> <!-- <chhead> is now mandatory -->
    <oneOrMore>
      <ref name="chrow"/>
    </oneOrMore>
  </element>

rule: Use <stepxmp> for an example illustrating the step.
Use <stepresult> to explain expected outcome of a step. Include only as necessary.
Only one <stepresult> per step. Nothing except <steptroubleshooting> can follow it.
rule_code:
<optional>
      <ref name="stepresult"/>
    </optional>
    <optional>
      <ref name="steptroubleshooting"/>
    </optional>
(RNG allows steptroubleshooting after stepresult, and only one stepresult is possible because it's under an optional ref, not zeroOrMore)

rule: Use <steptroubleshooting> (optional) to provide recovery info for step mistakes/errors. Consider if <stepresult> is included.
<steptroubleshooting> must be the last element within a <step> when included.
rule_code:
...
    <optional>
      <ref name="stepresult"/>
    </optional>
    <optional>
      <ref name="steptroubleshooting"/>
    </optional>
(This means steptroubleshooting is last if present.)

rule: <choicetable> <chhead> contains <choptionhd> (Option heading) and <chdeschd> (Description heading).
<choicetable> <chrow> contains <choption> and <chdesc>. Only one <choption> per <chrow>. Only one <chdesc> per <chrow>.
Writing Prerequisite Sections (Task): If no prerequisites, do not include <prereq>.
Writing Prerequisite Sections (Task): If prerequisite is in another topic, link to it with explanatory text.
Writing Prerequisite Sections (Task): Include each prerequisite in an unordered list (<ul>), even if only one.
rule_code: <element name="prereq">\n      <ref name="ul"/>  <!-- Now only <ul> is allowed -->\n    </element>

rule: Writing Prerequisite Sections (Task): Do not preface list with introductory sentence. <prereq> is first in <taskbody>.
Writing Context Sections (Task): Do not repeat info from <shortdesc>. If nothing to add, leave out <context>.
Writing Context Sections (Task): Use to answer 'who, what, why, when, where'. Should not replace concept topic.
Writing Context Sections (Task): For maintenance tasks, consider using for an overall image of part being maintained.

Writing Context Sections (Task): Do not include content directly in ; surround with block element (e.g.

).
Writing Context Sections (Task): Do not use <context> simply for a stem sentence introducing steps.
Writing Steps and Substeps (Task): Must include a <cmd> element in <step>/<substep>.
rule_code: <ref name="cmd"/> (as first child of step and substep)

rule: Writing Steps and Substeps (Task): <cmd> generally for single user action. Avoid being too granular. Write in imperative voice.
Writing Steps and Substeps (Task): Keep number of steps minimal. Break long procedures into smaller tasks.
Writing Steps and Substeps (Task): If orienting user or qualifying step, put that info before describing action in <cmd>.
Writing Steps and Substeps (Task): For safety concern, place <note> before <cmd>.
rule_code:
<ref name="cmd"/>  <!-- <cmd> is now the first element -->
    <optional>       <!-- Optional <note> can follow <cmd> -->
      <ref name="note"/>
    </optional>
(Note: The rule states 'place <note> ... *prior* to the <cmd>'. The RNG has <cmd> first then optional <note>. This is a mismatch. The RNG needs to be updated for this rule to be implemented=true as stated by the text. Assuming the textual rule is the desired one, current RNG implements this as `false`.)

rule: Writing Steps and Substeps (Task): Limit <cmd> to one sentence. Use additional step elements for more info.
Writing Steps and Substeps (Task): Try for only one level of steps. Limit <substeps> use. Flatten structure if most users need details.
Writing Steps and Substeps (Task): Do not use step/substep structure to provide alternate ways/conditions; create different topics.
Writing Steps and Substeps (Task): For <steps-unordered>, list in recommended order. Note prior step requirements if any.

Writing Steps and Substeps (Task): Use <choices> when the user has many ways to complete the step to achieve the same result. Use <choicetable> when the user has many options that lead to different results.
Including Task Results: Do not include <result> element if the result is obvious. Use illustrations wherever possible.

Writing Task Troubleshooting Sections: Include <steptroubleshooting> element at likely mistake points. Avoid language that implies user fault. Keep explanations short; link to longer topics for complex solutions.
Including Examples (Task): Use <example> section at end of task. Include for difficult-to-understand tasks/concepts. Choose relatable, average complexity examples. Exercise all steps.
Including Examples (Task): Do not include multiple scenarios in one example; use multiple <example> elements with <title> to differentiate.
rule_code:
<optional>
        <ref name="title"/>
      </optional>
(Allows title for differentiation, and task body allows optional example implying multiple can be sibling)

rule: Writing Postrequisites (Task): Do not include steps. Do not include obvious actions. Include information about criticality.
Concept topic structure: <concept> (req), <title> (req), <shortdesc> (req), <prolog> (req), <conbody> (req).
rule_code:
<element name="concept">
      <ref name="id-atts"/>
      <ref name="lang-atts"/>
      <ref name="title"/>
      <ref name="shortdesc"/>
      <ref name="prolog"/>
      <ref name="conbody"/>
    </element>

rule:
(Concept) can contain body elements (

,

    , ),
    elements, elements (all optional, any order).
rule_code:
<element name="conbody">
      <choice>
        <!-- Case 1: Only loose blocks -->
        <oneOrMore>
          <ref name="conbody.loose-blocks"/>
        </oneOrMore>
        <!-- Case 2: Only structural blocks -->
        <oneOrMore>
          <ref name="conbody.structural-blocks"/>
        </oneOrMore>
        <!-- Case 3: Loose blocks followed by structural blocks -->
        <group>
          <oneOrMore>
            <ref name="conbody.loose-blocks"/>
          </oneOrMore>
          <oneOrMore>
            <ref name="conbody.structural-blocks"/>
          </oneOrMore>
        </group>
      </choice>
    </element>

rule: <conbody> (Concept): can contain common block/inline elements if no <section> or <example> inserted. Once <section>/<example> used, all block elements must be within one.
rule_element: (This is implicitly handled by the conbody definition where loose blocks can exist, or structural blocks which then contain loose blocks)

rule: Use <section> (Concept) to organize subtopics. Must begin with <title>. Followed by another <section> or <example>.
rule_code:
<element name="section">
    <ref name="id-atts"/>
    <ref name="title"/>
    <oneOrMore>
      <choice>
        <ref name="p"/>
        ...
      </choice>
    </oneOrMore>
  </element>
(And conbody allows multiple structural blocks)

rule: Topics have flat structure; DITA does not support nested sections. For hierarchy, use multiple topics and map.
applicable_to: Concept, Task, Reference, Troubleshooting, Glossary terms, Learning overview, Scripts, Field definitions

rule: Use <example> (Concept) to illustrate content. Recommended (not required) to begin with <title>. Followed by another <example> or <section>.
rule_code:
<element name="example">
      <ref name="id-atts"/>
      <optional>
        <ref name="title"/>
      </optional>
      ...
    </element>
(And conbody allows multiple structural blocks)

rule: Writing concept topics: Should address one complete idea. Divide large subjects into smaller topics. Avoid transitional language assuming prior topic.
Writing concept topics: Use minimalist writing. Start general, add detail. Write most in paragraphs and unordered lists.
Writing concept topics: For ordered list in concept, ensure not writing a task. Typically relate to processes where user isn't primary actor.
Writing concept topics: To allow reuse, avoid transitional words between paragraphs. Use graphics with well-titled captions.
Writing concept topics: Do not start with a section. If using sections, always start with an introductory paragraph.
rule_code:
<choice>
        <!-- Case 1: Only loose blocks -->
        <oneOrMore>
          <ref name="conbody.loose-blocks"/>
        </oneOrMore>
        ...
        <!-- Case 3: Loose blocks followed by structural blocks -->
        <group>
          <oneOrMore>
            <ref name="conbody.loose-blocks"/>
          </oneOrMore>
          <oneOrMore>
            <ref name="conbody.structural-blocks"/>
          </oneOrMore>
        </group>
      </choice>
(This enforces that if structural blocks like section are used, they can be preceded by loose blocks (introductory paragraph))

rule: Dividing concept topic into sections: All sections must have a <title> element. Do not start a concept topic with a titled <section> (results in stacked headings).
rule_code: <ref name="title"/> (as a required child of section)

rule: Dividing concept topic into sections: If individual sections are long or can stand alone, consider creating multiple concept topics. Do not include only one section within the topic.
Including examples (Concept): The <title> element within an <example> is optional. Include only one example per <example> element. Try to include examples that apply to a wide range of users.
Reference topic structure: <reference> (req), <title> (req), <shortdesc> (req), <prolog> (req), <refbody> (req).
rule_code:
<element name="reference">
      <ref name="id-atts"/>
      <ref name="lang-atts"/>
      <ref name="title"/>
      <ref name="shortdesc"/>
      <ref name="prolog"/>
      <ref name="refbody"/>
    </element>

rule: <refbody> (Reference) can contain <table>, <section>, and <example> in any order and intermixed as needed.
rule_code:
<element name="refbody">
      <oneOrMore>
        <choice>
          <ref name="table"/>
          <ref name="simpletable"/>
          <ref name="section"/>
          <ref name="example"/>
          <ref name="p"/>
          <ref name="ul"/>
          <ref name="ol"/>
          <ref name="dl"/>
        </choice>
      </oneOrMore>
    </element>

rule: For reference topics with a required set of sections, if no information for a specific section, leave the section in with the text, 'N/A'.
Use a <table> element (CALS table) to create a table in reference topics.

Use the <section> element (Reference) to organize subtopics. Begin a section with a <title> unless it is the first element. Common block/inline elements nested within; cannot include these (except tables) outside <section>/<example>.
rule_code: (Section definition requires title, refbody allows section)

rule: Use the <example> element (Reference) to illustrate content. Recommended (not required) to begin with <title> unless it is the first element.
rule_code: (Example definition makes title optional, refbody allows example)

rule:
Writing reference topics: Avoid long blocks of narrative in

elements. Assume users understand basics. Make information easy to scan (lists, tables, charts).
Writing reference topics: No need for transition sentences or other structures for flow between sections.
Writing reference topics: Use <imagemap> elements when describing fields on screens or reports.
Troubleshooting topic structure (Ryffine) is based on the DITA 1.3 standard. Structure depends on the number of causes and solutions.
rule_code: (The entire RNG file defines the structure based on these elements)

rule: Troubleshooting elements: <condition> (optional), <troubleSolution> (required, container for <cause> and <remedy>), <cause> (optional), <remedy> (optional), <responsibleParty> (optional, in <remedy>).
rule_element: (These are defined with their respective cardinalities)

rule: <remedy> (Troubleshooting): Cannot include any block or inline elements directly. Instead, nest a <steps>, <steps-unordered>, or <steps-informal> element.
rule_code:
<element name="remedy">
      <ref name="title"/> <!-- Now mandatory -->
      <optional>
        <ref name="responsibleParty"/>
      </optional>
      <choice>
        <ref name="steps"/>
        <ref name="steps-unordered"/>
        <ref name="steps-informal"/>
      </choice>
    </element>

rule: Writing Condition Sections (Troubleshooting): Do not simply repeat title. Provide additional details. Include all observable symptoms. Use user's language. Don't confuse condition with cause. For error messages, include screen capture if possible.
Writing Diagnostic Sections (Troubleshooting): If >1 cause, include initial <troubleSolution> element for diagnostics (either <cause> or <remedy> section, not both).
rule_code:
<element name="troubleSolution">
      <choice>
        <group> <!-- Allows cause, then optional remedy(s) -->
          <ref name="cause"/>
          <zeroOrMore>
            <ref name="remedy"/>
          </zeroOrMore>
        </group>
        <oneOrMore> <!-- Allows remedy(s) only (cause would have been caught by the group above if present) -->
          <ref name="remedy"/>
        </oneOrMore>
      </choice>
    </element>
(Allows either cause then remedies, or just remedies. Forcing cause OR remedy requires a different structure or post-processing check)

rule: Writing Diagnostic Sections (Troubleshooting): Use <cause> section with table if symptoms immediately observable. Use <remedy> section with steps if user must act. Organize most common problems first. Title section 'Diagnostics'. Provide link to corresponding solution section.
rule_code:
<choice>
        <group> <!-- Case: Diagnostic table -->
        <ref name="title"/> <!-- Title "Diagnostics" (content not enforceable by RNG) -->
        <ref name="table"/> <!-- The diagnostic table -->
      </group>
        <group> <!-- Case: No table ... -->
          ...
        </group>
      </choice>

rule: Writing Cause Sections (Troubleshooting): If solution is same for all causes, describe all in a single <cause> section paired with <remedy>. Avoid language implying user fault. Keep explanations short.

Writing Remedy Sections (Troubleshooting): Ensure remedy section clearly tied to corresponding cause(s). Use <steps> element whenever possible. Consider reusing <steps> from task topics. Title the solution according to the cause it addresses.
rule_code:
<ref name="title"/> <!-- Now mandatory -->
      <optional>
        <ref name="responsibleParty"/>
      </optional>
      <choice>
        <ref name="steps"/>
        <ref name="steps-unordered"/>
        <ref name="steps-informal"/>
      </choice>

rule: Glossary entry structure: <glossentry> (req), <glossterm> (req), <glossdef> (req), <glossBody> (opt). Optional elements: <glossStatus>, <glossProperty>, <glossSurfaceForm>, <glossUsages>, <glossScopeNotes>, <glossSymbol>, <glossAlt>.
rule_code: (The elements and their optionality/requirement are defined here)

rule: Cannot include <title> or <shortdesc> element in a <glossentry> topic. <glossBody> is required only if defining a term with an acronym or abbreviation. Ryffine is not including metadata for glossary terms, so <prolog> not required.
rule_code:
<element name="glossentry">
      <ref name="id-atts"/>
      <ref name="lang-atts"/>
      <ref name="glossterm"/>
      <ref name="glossdef"/>
      <optional>
        <ref name="glossBody"/>
      </optional>
    </element>
(Absence of title, shortdesc, prolog enforces this. glossBody being optional also aligns.)

rule: Use the <glossterm> element to enter the term that will be described.

Use the element to provide a definition. If more than one definition applies, create a new glossary entry topic for each definition. Must contain one or more

.
rule_code:
<element name="glossdef">
      <oneOrMore>
        <ref name="p"/> <!-- Assumes 'p' from common elements is suitable -->
      </oneOrMore>
    </element>

rule: Use the <glossBody> element as a container for <glossSurfaceForm> and <glossAlt> elements. This element is required when defining terms with acronyms or abbreviations.
rule_code:
<choice>
        <group> <!-- Case: Acronym/Abbreviation is present (via glossAlt) -->
          <ref name="glossSurfaceForm"/>
          <ref name="glossAlt"/>
        </group>
        ...
      </choice>
(This structure for acronyms implies glossBody is used and contains these when acronyms are present.)

rule: In field description topics, nest the <glossStatus> element in <glossBody> to indicate field status (active, deprecated, removed) using @value attribute.
In field description topics, nest the <glossProperty> element in <glossBody> to indicate whether field is required, optional, calculated, derived, or user defined.
Use <glossSurfaceForm> (optional) to define the first-use form of the word.
rule_code:
<element name="glossSurfaceForm">
      <text/>
    </element>
(Its optionality is defined within glossBody)

rule: Use <glossUsage> (optional, in field descriptions) to include hints and tips for when a specific field would be best included in a report.
Use <glossScopeNote> (in field descriptions) to indicate the specific screen from UI where users enter data or the specific report(s) including the field.
Use <glossSymbol> (in field descriptions) if field is shown with an icon; use @href attribute to point to image file.
Use <glossAlt> element as a container for <glossAcronym> and <glossAbbreviation> elements.
Use <glossAcronym> element to define an acronym as an alternate form for the term in <glossterm>.
Use <glossAbbreviation> element to define an acronym or abbreviation as an alternate form for the term in <glossterm>.
Create a separate <glossentry> topic for each term. Immediately begin with <glossterm> followed by <glossdef>.

Writing glossary definitions: Use incomplete sentences. No lead-ins like 'A term is...'. If definition context-specific, preface with context. Limit to essential info. No second person. Do not use term/form of term to define itself. Avoid nesting definitions.
Defining terms within a topic: Ensure <glossentry> referenced in map with <glossref>. Embed term/acronym in <term> tag. Add @keyref attribute to <term> referencing @keys attribute in <glossref>.
applicable_to: Task, Concept, Reference, Troubleshooting, Learning overview, Scripts, Field definitions
rule_code:
<optional>
        <attribute name="keyref">
          <data type="string"/>
        </attribute>
      </optional> (in term)

<element name="glossref">
      <attribute name="href">
        <data type="string"/>
      </attribute>
 ...
</element> (glossref structure)

rule: Do not use <term> to define acronyms within the text. Instead, use <abbreviated-form>.
applicable_to: Task, Concept, Reference, Troubleshooting, Learning overview, Scripts, Field definitions

rule: Using Acronyms (in <glossentry>): Add <glossBody> after <glossdef>. Nest <glossSurfaceForm> in <glossBody> for first-use form. Add <glossAlt> after <glossSurfaceForm>. Nest <glossAcronym> in <glossAlt> for acronym.
rule_code:
<choice>
        <group> <!-- Case: Acronym/Abbreviation is present (via glossAlt) -->
          <ref name="glossSurfaceForm"/>
          <ref name="glossAlt"/>
        </group>
        ...
      </choice>

rule: Stylesheet treats <abbreviated-form> as if it were a <term> element for online presentations (rollover text), as DITA does not allow both <abbreviated-form> and <term> at the same time.
applicable_to: Task, Concept, Reference, Troubleshooting, Learning overview, Scripts, Field definitions

      <ref name="id-atts"/>
      <ref name="lang-atts"/>
      <ref name="title"/>
      <ref name="prolog"/>
      <ref name="learningOverviewbody"/>
    </element>

rule: <learningOverviewbody> structure: <lcIntro> (req), <lcAudience> (req), <lcDuration> (req), <lcPrereqs> (opt), <lcObjectives> (req), <lcResources> (opt), <section><title>Instructor Notes</title> (opt), <section> (opt), <section><title>Outline</title> (generated).

<element name="learningOverviewbody">
      <ref name="lcIntro"/>
      <ref name="lcAudience"/>
      <ref name="lcDuration"/>
      <optional>
        <ref name="lcPrereqs"/>
      </optional>
      <ref name="lcObjectives"/>
      <optional>
        <ref name="lcResources"/>

rule: Nest a <title> element in each and every one of the following sections of <learningOverviewBody> (lcIntro, lcAudience, lcDuration, lcPrereqs, lcObjectives, lcResources) to provide a heading. Template includes these.
rule_code: <ref name="title"/> (as direct child of lcIntro, lcAudience etc.)

rule: Use an element to provide a summary description of the training course. It must contain a and one or more <p>.
Use an <lcAudience> element to describe the intended audience for the training. It must contain a <title> and mixed content.
Use an <lcDuration> element to estimate time. It must contain a <title> and <lcTime>. <lcTime> has a required @time attribute and text content.
rule_code:
<element name="lcDuration">
        <ref name="title"/>
      <ref name="lcTime"/>
    </element>

<element name="lcTime">
      <attribute name="time">
        <data type="string"/>
      </attribute>
      <text/>
    </element>

rule: Use an element to list readings/activities student should complete prior. It must contain a and one or more <p>.
Use an <lcObjectives> element as container for lesson objectives. It must contain a <title>, optional <lcObjectivesStem>, and one or more <lcObjectivesGroup>.
<lcObjectivesStem> provides introductory sentence for objectives. It contains mixed content.
<lcObjectivesGroup> is a container topic for one or more <lcObjective> elements.
<lcObjective> contains the objective text directly, using <ph> elements for conrefs. Cannot use regular block elements within.
Use an element to list supporting content/readings. It must contain a and one or more <p>.
Optional <section><title>Instructor Notes</title> after <lcResources> to provide guidance to instructor.
Nest additional titled <section> elements as needed for any unique content that you want to include in the overview.
The agenda map will automatically end the overview topic with an auto-generated section that lists the contents (tasks) covered within the training.
Writing overview objectives: Format: 'Given CONDITION, the learner will be able to BEHAVIOR to STANDARD.'
Writing overview objectives: List circumstances for behavior, describe what user must know/do & how demonstrated, use measurable action verbs, specify criteria for performance.

rule: Relationship tables define and manage links to related topics within online deliverable. Use in DITA maps and bookmaps.

Relationship tables: Each row represents separate set of relationships. No relationships between rows. At least two cells in row should have references to establish relationship. Each cell can contain multiple topic refs (by default, no relationship between topics in same cell). Refs can be repeated in multiple rows.
Wherever possible, use DITA's automatic hierarchical linking to avoid need for creating relationships in relationship tables.

Relationship tables: Be careful not to duplicate links (e.g., if topic already has <xref>). Ensure all links take users to meaningful, related content. Limit number of relationships to < five per topic. Take time to validate links. When nesting maps, include reltables in map level common to all topics in relationship.
<reltable> element is child of <map> or <bookmap>. Contains <relheader> (optional) and one or more <relrow>.
<relheader> is container for column specifications (<relcolspec>). Each <reltable> should contain at least two <relcolspec>.
<relrow> defines relationships among topics in each row. Contains one or more <relcell>.
<relcell> defines topic references. Nest <topicref> elements for each topic involved, using @href. Number of <relcell> must match <relcolspec>. If no topic ref in a cell, add empty <relcell>.
Linking to Topics Within the Same Cell (Relationship Table): Group topics in cell with <topicgroup> and set @collection-type to 'family' (all related) or 'sequence' (Next/Previous links).
Creating One-Way Links (Relationship Table): Set @linking attribute in <topicref> to 'targetonly' (cannot link back from) or 'sourceonly' (cannot link back to as).
Linking attributes: @collection-type on <topicref> specifies how children relate to parent/each other (family, sequence).
Linking attributes: @conref points to specific element to include at point of reference (content inserted, not linked).

rule_code: <attribute name="href">\n        <data type="string"/>\n      </attribute> (present in all these definitions)

rule: Linking attributes: @linking on <topicref> in map/reltable controls direction of links (targetonly, sourceonly).
Linking attributes: @type on <xref> specifies target type for cross-reference (fig, table, li, fn, section). Note: @type on <note>/<hazardstatement> is for information type, not linking.

rule: File Naming Convention: Begin with indicator for file type + underscore (a_, c_, t_, tp_, r_, rfaq_, rfd_, rrh_, ts_, o_, g_, m_, lm_, bm_, coll_, key_). Add title as in topic/map <title> (lowercase, no spaces/special chars/punctuation). Full titles preferred; abbreviations for long names. Avoid duplicate file names. End with .dita or .ditamap.
applicable_to: Map, Bookmap, Task, Concept, Reference, Troubleshooting, Glossary terms, Learning overview, Scripts, Field definitions

rule: Map Metadata (<topicmeta>): Metadata specified in <topicmeta> within map overrides values from topic. Only use <topicmeta> for customer-facing metadata. Can use all same elements as <metadata> in Prolog, except index terms. <audience>, <category>, <keywords>, <prodinfo> do not need to be nested in <metadata> tag here.
rule_code:
<element name="topicmeta">
      <zeroOrMore>
        <choice>
          <ref name="navtitle"/>
          <ref name="shortdesc"/>
          <ref name="audience"/>
          <ref name="category"/>
          <ref name="keywords"/>
          <ref name="prodinfo"/>
        </choice>
      </zeroOrMore>
    </element>

rule: Do not specify keywords at the map level. Any metadata that will assist authors in locating topics should remain in topics themselves.
applicable_to: Map, Task, Concept, Reference, Troubleshooting, Glossary terms, Learning overview, Scripts, Field definitions

rule: To use <navtitle> in map's <topicmeta> instead of file's own title, include @locktitle='yes' on referring <topicref> or <mapref>.

Nest <shortdesc> element in <topicmeta> to provide short description for non-DITA items or to help users understand distinction between different contexts of same topic. Map-level <shortdesc> overrides topic's.
Bookmeta elements: Nest <authorinformation>, <publisherinformation>, <bookid>, <bookrights> in order specified within <bookmeta> element in bookmap.
Display attributes: 'frame' specifies if border should surround element and on what sides (top, bottom, topbot, all, sides, none).

rule: Display attributes: 'scale' specifies percentage to resize fonts/images in proportion to normal size (50-200). Primarily for print. Best practice: resize images in source file.

rule: Display attributes: 'outputclass' specifies special styling be used during output processing.

rule: Display attributes: 'rev' indicates specific revision level or tracks change to change request/problem report. Define value as version/release of product (e.g. rev='v1.r1'). Do not use for minor editorial changes unrelated to product change.
